title: Do top schools look at average GPA or focus on specific years? I slacked freshman year (3.5 unweighted but lots of honors) but got a 3.9 unweighted sophomore year (lots of honors, no AP). If I do well next year do I still have a shot? - Quora
tags: Grade Point Average and University Admissions

response.answer_text: Top schools look at both. Although an increasing trend in grades is more favorable than a declining trend in grades, in terms of GPA, you still won’t be able to compete with the many 4.0 applicants that apply to top schools. The good thing is grades aren’t everything. There are other parts of your application that are arguably more important than a perfect 4.0. Academic RigorIntellectual CuriosityDemonstrated commitment to a passionLeadership experienceEtcHowever, you will need to do exceptionally well in other parts of your application to make up for your “sub-standard” GPA. It’s not the time to slack off on your grades. You still have a chance, but realize that your GPA won’t be doing you any favors. So you’ll just need to let yourself shine somewhere else.

A2A. Do top schools look at average GPA or focus on specific years? I slacked freshman year (3.5 unweighted but lots of honors) but got a 3.9 unweighted sophomore year (lots of honors, no AP). If I do well next year do I still have a shot? All schools that use holistic review to select their freshmen evaluate the high school transcript for academic readiness, the ability to take college courses. The evaluation includes GPAs, how the GPAs were calculated, the classes taken, and the high school attended. GPA alone never determines admittance.
